verses.text: In the days when the judges ruled, there was a famine in the land. And a man from Bethlehem in Judah went to dwell in the territory of Moab with his wife and two sons.
verses.comment: The time of the judges was marked by repeated cycles of hardship and faithfulness, as well as God’s providential guidance. Bethlehem (“house of bread”) being struck by famine is ironic. This sets up the theme of God working even during suffering. The move to Moab foreshadows the inclusion of outsiders in God’s plan.

verses.text: The man’s name was Elimelech, his wife’s name Naomi, and his two sons were Mahlon and Chilion. They were Ephrathites from Bethlehem in Judah. They went to Moab and remained there.
verses.comment: Ephrathah is the ancient name of Bethlehem, establishing the messianic lineage (Matthew 1:5). The choice to dwell in Moab, a nation often opposed to Israel, highlights themes of exile, restoration, and divine providence.

verses.text: But Elimelech, Naomi’s husband, died, and she was left with her two sons.
verses.comment: Naomi’s widowhood foreshadows God’s concern for widows and orphans throughout Scripture (Ps. 68:5). The loss initiates Naomi’s journey of suffering and redemption.

verses.text: The sons took Moabite wives—one named Orpah and the other named Ruth. They lived there about ten years.
verses.comment: Israelites were generally discouraged from marrying foreigners (Deut. 7:3), yet Ruth becomes part of the messianic line (Matt 1:5). This hints at the universal call and God’s plan extending beyond boundaries.

verses.text: Then both Mahlon and Chilion also died, and Naomi was left without her two children and her husband.
verses.comment: Naomi's loss leaves her destitute. The spiritual meaning foreshadows God’s care for those in deep sorrow (Ps 34:18).

verses.text: Then Naomi arose with her daughters-in-law to return from the fields of Moab, for she heard that the Lord had visited his people and given them food.
verses.comment: God’s providence returns to Bethlehem, reminiscent of past deliverances and provision. This foreshadows greater spiritual bread in the future (John 6:32-35).

verses.text: So she left the place where she was, with her two daughters-in-law, and they began to journey back to the land of Judah.
verses.comment: The theme of returning from exile points to a pattern of restoration and return throughout salvation history (Ezra 1:3-7).

verses.text: Naomi said to her two daughters-in-law, 'Go back, each of you to your mother’s house. May the Lord deal kindly with you, as you have dealt with the dead and with me.'
verses.comment: The blessing of kindness ('hesed') is a key Old Testament theme—God’s steadfast love guiding His people and those who show loyalty.

verses.text: 'May the Lord grant that each of you find rest in the house of her husband.' She kissed them, and they raised their voices and wept.
verses.comment: Naomi prays for their security and peace—a foreshadowing of God’s rest and comfort for those who trust Him. Spiritual rest is further revealed in Christ (Matthew 11:28).

verses.text: But they said to her, 'No, we will return with you to your people.'
verses.comment: The daughters-in-law’s loyalty reflects the gospel call to leave behind former attachments for the sake of God’s kingdom (Luke 9:62).

verses.text: But Naomi replied, 'Turn back, my daughters; why would you go with me? Are there yet sons in my womb, that they may become your husbands?'
verses.comment: She references 'levirate marriage' customs, linking Ruth to Israel’s laws for family and redemption (Gen 38:8).

verses.text: 'Turn back, my daughters; go your way, for I am too old to have a husband. If I thought there was hope, even if I were to have a husband tonight and bear sons,'
verses.comment: Naomi emphasizes her helplessness, paralleling Sarah’s late hope for a child (Gen 18:11). God’s plans often arise out of human impossibility.

verses.text: 'Would you then wait until they were grown? Would you refrain from marrying? No, my daughters, it is exceedingly bitter to me for your sake, that the hand of the Lord has gone out against me.'
verses.comment: Naomi feels God’s judgment, a common motif in Old Testament lament (Job 19:21), yet God’s providence is already at work beneath the surface.

verses.text: They lifted up their voices and wept again. Orpah kissed her mother-in-law, but Ruth clung to her.
verses.comment: Ruth’s clinging echoes covenant loyalty ('hesed'). Both physical and spiritual fidelities are highlighted, anticipating the faithfulness demanded of Christ’s followers.

verses.text: And Naomi said, 'See, your sister-in-law has gone back to her people and to her gods; return after your sister-in-law.'
verses.comment: Returning to false gods is subtly contrasted to embracing the true faith. Fidelity to God is presented as a conscious choice, as it is throughout the New Testament.

verses.text: But Ruth said: 'Do not urge me to leave you or turn back from following you. For wherever you go, I will go, and wherever you lodge, I will lodge. Your people shall be my people, and your God my God.'
verses.comment: Ruth’s confession is a pledge of total devotion, paralleling conversion language (Gal 3:28). Her commitment is seen as both literal (embracing Israel) and spiritual (joining the people of God).

verses.text: 'Where you die, I will die, and there I will be buried. May the Lord do so to me, and more also, if anything but death parts me from you.'
verses.comment: Ruth calls on the Lord for witness—a solemn oath. 'Buried together' echoes biblical teachings about physical and spiritual unity (Matt 19:6), and the seriousness of covenant promises.

verses.text: When Naomi saw that Ruth was determined to go with her, she stopped urging her.
verses.comment: Ruth’s perseverance in loyalty points to the importance of steadfastness in faith and to the fruits of persistent devotion.

verses.text: The two of them went on until they came to Bethlehem. When they arrived in Bethlehem, the whole town was stirred because of them, and the women said, 'Is this Naomi?'
verses.comment: Bethlehem signifies promise and fulfillment, later associated with the birth of Christ. Naomi’s return creates anticipation for God’s restoration.

verses.text: She said to them, 'Do not call me Naomi; call me Mara, for the Almighty has dealt very bitterly with me.'
verses.comment: Name change from Naomi ('pleasant') to Mara ('bitter') echoes Israel’s experience at Marah (Exod 15:23). Bitterness is not the end—anticipates future transformation.

verses.text: 'I went away full, but the Lord has brought me back empty. Why call me Naomi, when the Lord has testified against me, and the Almighty has brought calamity upon me?'
verses.comment: Naomi’s lament is reminiscent of the psalmists’ complaint, yet these moments often mark a turning point when God’s hidden plan for good is revealed.

verses.text: So Naomi returned, and Ruth the Moabite her daughter-in-law with her, who came from the territory of Moab. They arrived in Bethlehem at the beginning of the barley harvest.
verses.comment: Barley harvest marks Passover season—timing is significant in salvation history. Foreshadows abundant blessing, bread from heaven, and Christ, the true bread born in Bethlehem.
